bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, September 18, 1940

div1.p: Hench thanks Webster for finding the old maps of the Havana Railroad. Hench is searching for information regarding the locations around Cuba that were once connected with the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, September 18, 1940
div1.opener:
September 18, 1940
Mr. R. S. Webster, Divisional Engineer
Ferrocarriles Unidos de la Habana
y Almacenes de Regla, Limitada
Compania Internacional
Vias y Obras
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Webster:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your real kindness in looking
up the old maps of the Havana Railroad. The identity of this railroad and the
date of its construction had an important bearing on the location of Camp Lazear.
The enclosed photograph which I found in the Army Medical Museum shows a model made
in Cuba in 1900, of the Post Hospital at Columbia Barracks, with a railroad and a
bridge over the railroad track. At the present time, just about where the houses
now are is the supposed location of Camp Lazear. I am sure this is entirely wrong.
On this site was erected a small temporary tent hospital, where were brought from
Camp Lazear experimental cases which developed yellow fever at Camp Lazear a mile
away from Columbia Barracks. Do you have any idea where I could find out when this
bridge was removed? You say that you remember in 1906 seeing what was represented
to be the huts of Camp Lazear. Do you have any idea where this was? Was it near
the railroad track, or was it on the San Jose farm on the Calzada Real de Marianao,
about a mile from Columbia Barracks?

Thank you for your information regarding my getting a map from the War
Department. As your maps were not dated, I at first had considerable difficulty in
identifying them from your letter, but believe I have finally done so, and wonder
if you would confirm (assuming that you have a copy of your letter to me) my inter-
pretation of the maps and your statements. I have drawn on a separate sheet my
understanding of the dates when these railroads were put down.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
